name: Ben Horowitz
background: Ben Horowitz (born 1966) is an American businessman, venture capitalist, and author. Co-founder and general partner at Andreessen Horowitz (a16z). Former CEO of Opsware (Loudcloud), sold to HP for $1.6B. Authored NYT bestsellers 'The Hard Thing About Hard Things' (2014) and 'What You Do Is Who You Are' (2019). Background: BA CS Columbia, MS CS UCLA; roles at Netscape, AOL.

principles.name: Culture Defined by Actions Under Stress
principles.description: Culture is 'what you do when no one is watching' or under pressure, not posters. Shape via rituals, hiring, promotions, firings. Examples: Samurai (death meditations), pirates (mutiny prevention), prisons (gang loyalty).
principles.falsification: When culture defined by actions under stress leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Hire/Fire for Cultural Fit in Extremes
principles.description: Promote based on behavior under stress. 'If you want a samurai culture, promote samurai.' Fire misfits decisively.
principles.falsification: When hire/fire for cultural fit in extremes leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: No Clear Playbook for Hard Things
principles.description: Business platitudes fail crises. Real leadership: Make painful calls, communicate politically incorrect truths.
principles.falsification: When no clear playbook for hard things leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Peacetime vs Wartime CEO
principles.description: Peacetime CEO (market dominance): Focuses on expansion, broad input, process. Wartime CEO (existential threat): Focuses survival, strict alignment, paranoia, directness, violation of peacetime rules. 'One-size-fits-all management is dangerous.' Switch modes based on context.
principles.falsification: When peacetime vs wartime ceo leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
